Ornette Coleman once said that â€œSound is to people what the sun is to light.â€ Sound is foundational to the human and it enhances our other senses. Like my previous Black Lives Matter playlist and past ENGL 125 playlists, I offer this playlist in relation to my current ENGL 125 courses focused on music, literature, and popular culture. Music is a through line of the two primary textsâ€”Esi Edugyanâ€™s Half-Blood Blues and Alan Moore and Dave Gibbonsâ€™s Watchmenâ€”and the anthemic refrain of Public Enemyâ€™s â€œFight the Powerâ€ punctuates the final work studied in this course: Spike Leeâ€™s Do the Right Thing. Music unifies and celebrates, but it can also resist and serve as protest. From Billie Holidayâ€™s â€œStrange Fruitâ€ (write-up on my #BLM playlist) to Rage Against the Machineâ€™s â€œKilling in the Name,â€ music has played an integral role in the pursuit of social justice. That all said, get comfortable. Grab a cup of tea, coffee, or your beverage of choice, and sit back and listen.

I also recommend that you check out the Student Playlist for the course, from here.

CONTENTS

INTRO: Talking Heads, â€œOnce in a Lifetimeâ€ and DJ TechnÃ©, â€œAnother Worldâ€

Week 1: Feelinâ€™ Blue: Johnson, Parker, Bessie, Billie, and Armstrong

Week 2 (Half-Blood Blues): King Oliver and Oscar Peterson

Week 3 (Half-Blood Blues): Bessie Smith and Jelly Roll Morton

Week 4 (Half-Blood Blues): Louis Armstrong, â€œWest End Bluesâ€ (1928) and Ella Fitzgerald, Ella in Berlin (1960)

Week 6 (Watchmen): Bob Dylan, â€œDesolation Rowâ€ (1965)

Week 7 (Watchmen): Nina Simone, â€œPirate Jennyâ€ and Billie Holiday, â€œYouâ€™re My Thrillâ€

Week 8 (Watchmen): Bob Dylan and Jimi Hendrix, â€œAll Along the Watchtowerâ€ (1968) and John Cale, â€œSanitiesâ€ (1982)

Week 9: Watchmen (2019): The Ink Spots and Eartha Kitt

Week 10: Itâ€™s Bigger than Hip Hop

Week 11: DJing and Wayde Compton: Kid Koala and Charlie Pride

Week 12: Public Enemy, â€œFight the Powerâ€

Intro: Talking Heads, â€œOnce in a Lifetimeâ€ and DJ TechnÃ©, â€œPortalsâ€

David Byrne speaks about the coronavirus as an opportunity for change, and music is all about change and adaptation. Byrne led the rock/new wave band Talking Heads for nearly 30 years. Talking Heads have a number of albums that appear on Rolling Stoneâ€™s list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time, and they are probably most known for their song, â€œPsycho Killer.â€ Another one of their well-known songs, and the focus of our intro listening is the obfuscate, â€œOnce in a Lifetimeâ€ (produced by Brian Eno from Remain in Light). Sonically, the song is inspired by the Afrobeat sound of Fela Kuti, and lyrically Byrne borrows from the cadences and antiphony of sermonizing preachers (see the lyrics). In part, the song deals with the pointlessness of not being content with what you have. It is impossible to remove the water at the bottom of the ocean and there is no way to stop the flow of life. There is certainly a lesson here, especially in terms of how we adapt and try to remain content during the challenges presented by COVID-19. In an interview with Time Out, Byrne describes how the song came from â€œevangelists I recorded off the radio while taking notes and picking up phrases I thought were interesting directions. Maybe Iâ€™m fascinated with the middle class because it seems so different from my life, so distant from what I do. I canâ€™t imagine living like that.â€ The song has also been analyzed as an invective against consumerism, but the central question the song asks is â€œHow did I get here?â€ A question, we can ask ourselves as individuals and as a species. On NPR, musician Travis Morrison praised the lyrics saying it is the perfect song: â€œThe lyrics are astounding â€“ they are meaningless and totally meaningful at the same time. Thatâ€™s as good as rock lyrics get.â€ What do you hear in them, and does the technologically outdated, but certainly interesting, music video for the song clarify its meaning? Probably not, but check it out.

Another song worth mentioning is Byrneâ€™s Broadway cover of Janelle Monaeâ€™s anthemic â€œHell You Talmbout,â€ which functions as a protest and uses call-and-response as the names of victims of police violence are shouted out. I am sharing the original Monae version, which feels as timely as ever, as it is not available on Spotify (but you can check out Byrneâ€™s version there).

Lastly, I want to share my live track, â€œPortals.â€ The track opens with a sample from the Man Booker Prize-winning Indian novelist Arundhati Roy speaking about the coronavirus pandemic as a portal: â€œIt is a portal, a gateway between one world and the next.â€ With systemic injustices more visible than ever, she asks us to use this opportunity to imagine another world, which is echoed in the second part of the performance as Sun Ra envisions music as another language. There is freedom in sound (especially when it is open to different styles) to dream and shape the future, which fits with Sun Raâ€™s vision of music as a gateway to a better world. If you listen closely, you will also hear vocal samples from Billie Holiday, Miles Davis, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Charles Mingus. Will we ignore the rupture the pandemic created and return to â€œnormal,â€ or will we improvise and step through the portal into another world?

A slightly different version of song can be heard on my album, Portals.

Week 1: Feelinâ€™ Blue: Johnson, Parker, Bessie, Billie, AND Armstrong

â€œI contend that the Negro is the creative voice of America, is creative America, and it was a happy day in America when the first unhappy slave was landed on its shores.â€ â€”Duke Ellington, The Duke Ellington Reader, 147

â€œThere is no true American music but the wild sweet melodies of the Negro slave.â€ â€”W.E.B. Du Bois, The Souls of Black Folk 7

I realize there is a lot of music for this week. Too much to fully grasp the meaning of all of the songs, but hopefully even reading through these short write-ups and having the playlist playing while you read the material, or think through it, will prove helpful and insightful. Esi Edugyan also made a written playlist to accompany her text, which you can find on VIULearn in the folder for this weekâ€™s class. This week is all about the blues and jazz.

The form of the blues comprises work songs, spirituals, field hollers, shouts, chants, and ballads, among other styles. However, it took some time before the blues were as classically ubiquitous and cross-cultural as they are today. As the Du Bois epigraph elucidates, and as James Weldon Johnson accurately predicted, â€œThe day will come when this slave music will be the most treasured heritage of the American Negroâ€ (Autobiography 1197). The blues plants the roots of much music: it is pervasive in jazz, provides the foundation of rhythm and blues, and the twelve-bar blues progression can even be heard throughout rock and roll. One particularly common feature of blues music is the blue note, which for expressive function is sung or played flattened or bent (from the minor 3rd to the major 3rd) relative to the pitch of the major scale. The idiom itself, â€œthe blues,â€ refers to the â€œblue devils,â€ implicating melancholy and sadness with an early use of the term appearing in George Colmanâ€™s one-act farce Blue Devils. Some early innovators of the blues are W.C. Handy (known as the Father of Blues), Bessie Smith, Gertrude â€œMaâ€ Rainey, Mamie Smith, Lead Belly, Robert Johnson, and too many others to list here. What is interesting to notice about this tentative list is how prominent women blues figures were in the creation, innovation, and dissemination of the blues, as female vaudeville blues singers were eminently popular in the 1920s.The blues genreâ€”and the spirituals preceding itâ€”helped materialize a classical African American canon of music (a formal counter canon to the European classical tradition), which provided potent standards off of which other artists could riff, beginning with the early spirituals. Case in point: the Negro Spirituals â€œSwing Low, Sweet Chariotâ€ and â€œGo Down Mosesâ€ have been covered and recorded on thousands of records, becoming standards, with everyone from Louis Armstrong, Etta James, Duke Ellington, Johnny Cash, Parliament, The Grateful Dead, and hip-hop group Bone Thugs and Harmony covering the former, to everyone from Grant Green, Fats Waller, Archie Shepp, and Will Smith on the sitcom The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air covering the latter. The blues have the power to connect people across diverse backgrounds and time periods, and represents, as Black liberation theologian James H. Cone argues in The Spirituals and the Blues, â€œThe power of the song in the struggle for black survivalâ€”that is what the spirituals and blues are aboutâ€ (1).

Jazz, similar to the blues, is a distinct musical form, prominently of African American origin, which emerged in the United States in the early decades of the twentieth century, although ragtime from the 1890s is also a type of jazz. Similar to the blues, jazz incorporates, adapts, and subverts other musical elements, with early influences including â€œAfrican and European music, American folk music, marching band music, plantation songs, spirituals and gospel music, minstrelsy, ragtime and the bluesâ€ (Stanbridge 286). Jazz is largely defined by its ability to amalgamate other forms, along with the musicâ€™s broader techniques, which include various rhythmic properties, from swing and syncopation to complex harmonic languages, as well as an overarching focus on improvisation.

The first song I want to draw your attention to is Robert Johnsonâ€™s â€œCross Road Bluesâ€ (also known as â€œCrossroadsâ€). Recorded back in 1936 the song is about the crossroads in Mississippiâ€”â€œI went to the crossroad, fell down on my kneesâ€â€”where Johnson supposedly sold his soul to the devil in exchange for his musical talents. The song was popularized by Eric Claptonâ€”who deeply admired Johnsonâ€”in the late â€˜60s. Another standard and related Johnson track is â€œMe and the Devil Bluesâ€ (1937), which tells the story of the devil knocking on Johnsonâ€™s door and telling him that itâ€™s time to go. Notice the call and response technique as various lines are repeated with some spontaneous vocal alteration. This antiphonic form is a big part of the blues and jazz, and it would later be heard in punk and hip-hop music. I remixed Johnsonâ€™s track with Bessie Smithâ€™s â€œDevilâ€™s Gonna Git You,â€ along with film and art, which you can view, here.

Hopefully, you had the chance to read James Baldwinâ€™s â€œSonnyâ€™s Blues,â€ which introduces us to a few pivotal figures of jazz, namely Louis Armstrong and Charlie Parker. While Armstrong is redeemed in Half-Blood Blues, he is considered â€œold-time, down home crapâ€ (although check out his â€œWhat Did I do to be so Black and Blueâ€ for its persistent themes) by Sonny largely because he wants to play what is new and cutting edge for his time: Bebop music. Iâ€™ve written about the power of Bebop music and its relation to hip-hop before, but what is so exciting about Charlie Parker for Sonny is that he took the music somewhere completely new as heard in â€œKo Koâ€ or â€œOrnithology,â€ which is a contrafactâ€”that is, a newly created melody written over the chord progressions of another song, in this instance the standard â€œHow High the Moon.â€ Sonny also covers â€œAm I Blueâ€ (notably recorded and performed by Billie Holiday) and makes it his own.

Many of these songs would make for excellent choices for your close reading if you decide to go that route.

Week 2 (Half-Blood Blues): King Oliver and Oscar Peterson

I hope you are enjoying Half-Blood Blues. If you were finding the language and style difficult, I also hope that it is getting easier for you as you work through it. There are a number of musical references throughout the novel and this week I want to draw your attention to two of them.

â€œCrowder told Armstrong Hiero reminded him of King Oliver in his primeâ€ (84) â€¦ â€œHave you ever seen King Oliver?â€ (111)

The novel talks a lot about Louis Armstrong (and later features him as a character) and Armstrong is considered one of the great innovators of jazz, but without King Oliver (1881-1938) we might not get Louis Armstrong. Oliver was both a mentor and teacher of Armstrong. As Armstrong says, in Satchmo: My Life In New Orleans, â€œif it had not been for Joe Oliver, Jazz would not be what it is today.â€ Iâ€™ve added both â€œRiverside Bluesâ€ and â€œSpeakeasy Bluesâ€ to the Spotify playlist.

While you havenâ€™t gotten to it yet, it doesnâ€™t spoil anything to let you know that the novel allows draws in Canada and jazz.

â€œIâ€™m from Montreal â€¦ Little Burgundyâ€ (108).

We learn that Delilah is from Little Burgundy in Montreal, which is the home of famous jazz musicians Oliver Jones and Oscar Peterson. You can view a short Wikipedia article that I wrote about a legendary club in Little Burgundy named â€œRockheadâ€™s Paradiseâ€ if you want to learn a little more about the history.

While there are number of Canadian jazz songs I could add, I will share one from Oscar Peterson. Drawing on the energy of the black church, and speaking across borders, Black Montreal-based musician Oscar Peterson conceived of â€œHymn to Freedom,â€ which was sung in various places in the States as an anthem to the Civil Rights Movement.

Also, for those interested in learning more about jazz music, see the documentary Jazz (link posted to VIULearn) as the documentary provides more detail about the man and legend, Louis Armstrong. In particular, later we will view the short clip on the novelty number called â€œHeebie Jeebies,â€ which Armstrong sang with vocal improvisations. Innovation is often a result of chance, and Louis Armstrongâ€™s impromptu scatting in â€œHeebie Jeebiesâ€ (the first scat caught on a recording) was the result of a mistake: as the legend goes, Armstrongâ€™s lyric sheet fell while recording and so he began to scat/improvise.

You can hear the song (and the others) on the Spotify playlist.

Week 3 (Half-Blood Blues): Bessie Smith and Jelly Roll Morton

â€œHe was playing Empty Bed Blues, but doing it so coy it ainâ€™t sound nothing like itself.â€ (122)

Bessie Smith was a major figure of the blues (we will watch the film Bessie about her), and she, along with others like Ma Rainey represent, as observed by Angela Davis, a â€œblack working-class social consciousness,â€ while moreover they â€œforeshadowed a brand of protest that refused to privilege racism over sexism, or the conventional public realm over the private as the preeminent domain of powerâ€ (Blues Legacies 42). And so, (in tandem with its often-bawdy nature), the blues genre was, as Davis concludes, â€œresponsible for the dissemination of attitudes toward male supremacy that had decidedly feminist implicationsâ€ (55). In a moment that leaves Sid very jealous, Delilah and Hiero perform Bessie Smithâ€™s â€œEmpty Bed Bluesâ€ (originally from 1928). You can read the lyrics here and listen to the song below (also on the playlist).

What do you think this song is about? Read the lyrics while listening to the song and then come back here. Iâ€™ll waitâ€¦

Okay. Did you listen to the song and read the lyrics? It is full on innuendos about sex (â€œcoffee grinderâ€) and even references performing cunnilingus: her new lover is a â€œdeep sea diverâ€ who can â€œstay down at the bottomâ€ holding his breath. No wonder Sid is jealous.

Deeply personal and explicit lyrics have always been part of the blues. At one point in the novel Jelly Roll Morton is mentioned. Born in 1890 Jelly Roll Morton is one of the earliest jazz artists and he even claimed to have invented the music in 1902 (this is disputed). He also played in Vancouver cabarets as early as 1919 and as late as 1921. He played piano, gambled, drank, told bawdy jokes, and sang during his residency at the Patricia in Vancouver. He also wrote some very explicit music, such as â€œWininâ€™ Boys Bluesâ€ (recorded by Alan Lomax in 1939).

Warning: the song below is very explicit and you may find it offensive (lyrics, here). Thereâ€™s a clean version of it on the Spotify playlist, as well as a version by singer Stephanie Niles with the original explicit lyrics. Does our understanding of the song change when a woman sings it?

There are many other songs of a similar nature, such as â€œTravelling Riverside Bluesâ€ (also added to the playlist). I guess weâ€™ve been singing and writing about sex for as long as weâ€™ve been writing and singing.

WEEK 4: LOUIS ARMSTRONG, â€œWEST END BLUESâ€ (1928) AND ELLA FITZGERALD, ELLA IN BERLIN (1960)

It is hardly an understatement to say Louis Armstrong helped invent modern time. â€œWest End Bluesâ€ is a multi-strain twelve-bar blues composition by Joe â€œKingâ€ Oliver that Armstrong uniquely makes his own. The opening is one of the great cadenzas in modern music and it helped define jazz as a soloistâ€™s art. Make sure you watch the segment on â€œWest End Bluesâ€ from Jazz in the lecture on VIULearn. Armstrong continues to inspire musicians, such as DJ Kid Koala, whose â€œBasin Street Bluesâ€ riffs on another Armstrong track.

Also, worth mentioning is Ella Fitzgeraldâ€™s incredible live album, Mack the Knife: Ella in Berlin (1960). In her version of â€œMac the Knife,â€ Ella forgot the lyrics and improvised new ones on the spot showing her incredible skill as a consummate improviser.

Equally impressive and one of the best scat performances ever recorded is Ellaâ€™s version of â€œHow Hight the Moon.â€ The way Ella uses her voice like a horn, her references to Charlie Parkerâ€™s â€œOrnithology,â€ and her ability to improvise upon a standard, is absolutely stunning. One must simply hear it to believe it. Enjoy.

Week 6 (Watchmen): Bob Dylan, â€œDesolation Rowâ€ (1965)

At midnight all the agents

And the superhuman crew

Come out and round up everyone

That knows more than they do

-Bob Dylan, â€œDesolation Rowâ€

As Dave Gibbonsâ€”the illustrator behind Watchmenâ€”wrote in his 2013 preface to the book: â€œIt began with Bob Dylan.â€ This song formed the spark that would one day ignite Watchmen: â€œThese lines must have also lodged in Alanâ€™s consciousness for, nearly twenty years later, Dylanâ€™s words eventually provided the title of the first issue of our comic book series WATCHMEN.â€ I hardly have the space here to describe a song like â€œDesolation Rowâ€ in detail, but I suggest you listen to the song in its entirety with the lyrics (and detailed notes) open on Genius. The song is an 11-minute epic of entropy (comprised of 10 verses) that features a large cast of iconic characters (historical, biblical, fictional, and literary). The song was the final song on Dylanâ€™s classic, Highway 61 Revisited and the lyrics move between the surreal and the hardships and realities of the Holocaust and post-World War II society. Desolation Row plays on the expression â€œskid row,â€ which is used to describe a seedy run-down part of town. Some interpretations have read the song as an allegory for the Holocaust, but part of the power of the song is that it resists simple interpretation, much like the graphic novel we are now reading. The band, My Chemical Romance performed a cover of the song for the 2009 soundtrack of Watchmen, but that film actually opens with another Dylan song.

Even three chapters in, youâ€™ve likely noticed that music runs through the veins of Watchmen as chapters and themes are shaped by individual songs and artists. A song like Dylanâ€™s â€œDesolation Row,â€ which moves across time and space from Nero to Einstein, speaks to the possibilities of the graphic novel as an artform informed by music (and other media). The first three chapters also feature Elvis Costelloâ€™s â€œThe Comedians,â€ Wagnerâ€™s â€œRide of the Valkyries,â€ The Policeâ€™s â€œWalking on the Moon,â€ and references to The Beatles and Elvis (but while you likely know his version of â€œHound Dog,â€ how many know of Big Mama Thorntonâ€™s earlier, and frankly, better version). These have all been added to the playlist.

WEEK 7 (WATCHMEN): NINA SIMONE, â€œPIRATE JENNYâ€ AND BILLIE HOLIDAY, â€œYOUâ€™RE MY THRILLâ€

The majority of the musical references in this weekâ€™s Watchmen readings are in Chapter 7, but there is also a coded one in Chapter 5. In Chapter 5, The Black Freighter (a reference from â€œPirate Jennyâ€) takes on symbolic meaning in the comic-within-the-comic as a revenge fantasy, but the song is also endued with the spirit of overcoming anti-Black racism. The use of music in Chapter 7 highlights Dan and Laurieâ€™s age gap, their nostalgia for the past, and their unfolding romance.

â€œPirate Jennyâ€ is a song from The Threepenny Opera written by Brecht and composer Kurt Weill. In Half-Blood Blues we listened to â€œMack the Knifeâ€ from that same opera. Nina Simone included the song on her 1964 album, Nina Simone in Concert, which featured other civil right songs such as â€œOld Jim Crowâ€ and a track we previously listened to, â€œMississippi Goddam.â€ â€œPirate Jennyâ€ is a song about a maid who imagines herself getting vengeance for the contempt she endures from the townspeople. She teams up with pirates from the Black Freighter and kills everyone and sails away to sea. Simone adapts the song into an African American context and uses â€œThe Black Freighterâ€ as â€œmetaphor for an African-American force powerful enough to destroy the racism and intolerance of the American South. Simone did not perform the song often, saying that it took so much energy out of her that it took her seven years to recover each timeâ€ (Mary Borsellino, Watchmen and Music). It is also worth noting that the song was a major influence on Bob Dylan who would record â€œDesolation Rowâ€ (the genesis of Watchmen) just a few years later.

Hereâ€™s Simoneâ€™s 1964 live version, but also check out her live version from 1992 that provides important context.

In Chapter 7 we get a number of music references, including Devo, Billie Holiday, and Nat King Cole. Many of these references are picked up in both the Snyder film and Lindelofâ€™s HBO series, including Nat King Coleâ€™s â€œUnforgettableâ€ and Billie Holidayâ€™s â€œYouâ€™re My Thrill.â€ In part, music functions as a cultural marker of connection or disconnection and it highlights the stark difference between Laurie and Dan in terms of age. Laurieâ€™s Devo reference goes over Danâ€™s head while Laurie is unable to recognize the voice of Billie Holiday, which plays just before they have sex.

Week 8 (Watchmen): Bob Dylan and Jimi Hendrix, â€œAll Along the Watchtowerâ€ (1968) and John Cale, â€œSanitiesâ€ (1982)

Chapter 10â€™s title of Watchmen is a reference to Bob Dylanâ€™s song â€œAll Along the Watchtowerâ€ (1967/68): the song is partially based on Isaiah 21, the prophecy of the fall of Babylon. The song is not only the source of the chapterâ€™s title, but it provides imagery that is quoted and echoed in the chapter: â€œTwo riders were approaching, and the wind began to howl.â€ However, the really iconic version of this song appears on Jimi Hendrixâ€™s Electric Ladyland album released around the same time as Dylanâ€™s version. Everyone from Eric Clapton, Neil Young, and Pearl Jam have covered the song, but Hendrixâ€™s version is the most well-known and potent.

The final chapter of Watchmen, Chapter 12, gets its title from a 1982 John Cale song, â€œSanctus (Sanities).â€ The song ends with the lyrics, â€œAll so that it would be a stronger world / A strong though loving world / To die in.â€ Moore slightly misquotes these lines at the very end of the graphic novel, and we get a paraphrased version by Adrian Veidt in Lindelofâ€™s Watchmen series (2019).

WEEK 9: WATCHMEN (2019): THE INK SPOTS AND EARTHA KITT

Damon Lindelofâ€™s Watchmen is full of music. Iâ€™ve added a few key songs to playlist from various episodes, but I want to focus on a few that I discuss in my lecture for this week from episode 6, â€œThis Extraordinary Being.â€ In that episode we see Hooded Justice release years of hurt, trauma, and aggression on a group of Klansmen. The scene is also beautifully choreographed in its kinesis and the song â€œI Donâ€™t Want to Set the World on Fireâ€ by The Ink Spots is a clever choice not only for the juxtaposition between the action and violence but in the layered meaning of the group name and song. The episode features three songs by The Ink Spots and the name of the group recalls a Rorschach test. Rorschach was one of the main characters of the original series and a Rorschach test is used to examine oneâ€™s personality and emotional functioning. The song playing, â€œI Donâ€™t Want to Set the World on Fireâ€ was used in commercials in the 1980s, which is when the original Watchmen was set and one of those commercials was for a perfume, which again reminds us of Nostalgia from the original comics. This nostalgia and heritage, a reminder where one comes from as well as the history of hate that pervades the present is entangled throughout the episode. We also get two other songs from Ink Spots: â€œWe Three (My Echo, My Shadow, And Me)â€ and â€œWhispering Grass (Donâ€™t Tell the Trees).â€

Lastly, we get Eartha Kittâ€™s â€œSmoke Gets in Your Eyesâ€ when Hooded Justice infiltrates the Cyclops plot. The song fits the episodeâ€™s focus on fire, but it goes deeper than that. Kittâ€”a Black woman known for her song â€œSanta Babyâ€â€”was also known for her masked role as Cat woman for the 1960s series of Batman. We are being shown how media can demonize and create stereotypes and how it also has the power to resist and undo them. Hooded Justice literally and figuratively burns it down. I hope you enjoyed the TV series and its clever use of music throughout.

Donâ€™t forget to check out my full lecture for this week, here.

Week 10: Itâ€™s Bigger than Hip Hop

Hip-hop music and culture is a chiaroscuro of social consciousness and mainstream commodification, a chameleonesque art form that adapts to every environment it encounters, a personal saviour and communitarian mobilizer born out of a disenfranchised youth movement in the post-industrial urban nightmare of Americaâ€™s neglected ghettos. There are many songs I could highlight here, but Iâ€™ve kept it to six songs (3 American and 3 Canadian).

Iâ€™ve been listening to EL-P and Killer Mike since the early 2000s and so I was thrilled when the two formed Run the Jewels back in 2013. The fervour of dissent in their fourth offering (2020) feels louder and more urgent with recent protests and Anti-Black racism and killings in North America. One of the most powerful verses on the entire album comes from Killer Mike on â€œWalking in the Snowâ€ where he raps: â€œAnd you so numb you watch the cops choke out a man like me / Until my voice goes from a shriek to whisper, â€˜I canâ€™t breatheâ€™ / And you sit there in the house on couch and watch it on TV.â€ Given this track was recorded months ago it is about Eric Garner, but it is also inadvertently about George Floyd too. Despite the nearly six years between these events, and the very public spectacle of the unjust killings, the lyrics underscore the perpetual cycle of Americaâ€™s racist violence. This spirit of protestâ€”although the album is still full of the usual braggadocio lyricism the two are known forâ€”runs through the veins of the album. The first single (released back in late April)â€”â€œOoh La Laâ€â€” is a homage to the old school for the present moment and features veterans DJ Premier and Greg Nice. The video for the song, as described by RTJ â€œis a fantasy of waking up on a day that there is no monetary system, no dividing line, no false construct to tell our fellow man that they are less or more than anyone else.â€ Iâ€™d also be remiss to not mention â€œâ€œJU$T,â€ which features Pharrell Williams and Rage Against the Machineâ€™s Zack de la Rocha and a classic protest chorus: â€œLook at all these slave masters posinâ€™ on yoâ€™ dollar (Get it, yeah).â€ Kill Your Masters.

Speaking of America, Childish Gambinoâ€™s â€œThis is Americaâ€ (2018) remains a visceral and surreal statement for addressing gun violence, racism, and police brutality in America: â€œThis is America / Donâ€™t catch you slippinâ€™ now / Look at how Iâ€™m livinâ€™ now / Police be trippinâ€™ now / Yeah, this is America.â€ In the video, directed by Hiro Murai, who also directed the incredible â€œTeddy Perkinsâ€ episode of Atlanta, Gambino plays with the Jump Jim Crow caricature, as he directly deals with Americaâ€™s persistent violence. Youâ€™ve likely seen the video for Gambinoâ€™s â€œThis is America,â€ but even if you have, itâ€™s worth another close watch.

Anderson .Paakâ€™s â€œLockdownâ€ speaks to the COVID-19 lockdown as a kind of container that makes systemic injustices more visible than ever, and which overfills and explodes as weâ€™ve seen in recent protests: â€œYou shoulda been downtown, the people are rising / We thought it was a lock down â€¦ Sicker than the covid how they did him on the ground / Speaking of the covid is it still goin around? / Oh why donâ€™t you tell me bout the lootin whatâ€™s that really all about? / Cause they throw away Black lives like paper towels.â€ Itâ€™s often easier to talk about the past, but I feel that Anderson really captures this moment in relation to the ongoing struggle for Black liberation. Also, if you havenâ€™t seen The Free Nationals featuring Anderson .Paakâ€™s Tiny Desk Concert, do yourself a favour and watch that! âœŠğŸ¾

There is a long history of hip-hop culture and music in Canada as well as a long history of Black resistance going back to slavery in Canada. Critic Rinaldo Walcott usefully contends that â€œwhat is at stake in Canadian hip hop is a refiguring of an elaboration of the urban landscape of Canada and by extension the urban landscape of North Americaâ€”black and otherwiseâ€ (â€œMethodologyâ€ 239). In Canadian hip-hop, narratives of belonging and unbelonging resist simple reductions of multiculturalism and ask us to reconsider the scope of Anti-Black racism, the nation-state, and geographical boundaries.

The first Canadian track is from Maestro Fresh Wes. Maestro Fresh Wesâ€™s 1989 â€œLet Your Backbone Slideâ€ was the first Canadian hip-hop single to break into the US Billboard chart. But, it is his track â€œNothinâ€™ At Allâ€ (1991) from his follow-up album that I want to highlight, which directly looks at Canada as country a â€œplagued with racism.â€ Despite this, Wes rightly celebrates Black excellence.

To the guys that draw lines and make the borders real

But then bend the rules when thereâ€™s more to drill

Donâ€™t turn away the stateless, think of the waste

If one in three refugees is a Lauryn Hill

â€”Shad, Flying Colours, â€œFam Jamâ€
